study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gelatin-based polymeric scaffold functionalized with VEGF for culturing insulin-producing cells as a potential therapeutic strategy for diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that gelatin-based scaffolds, when neutralized and functionalized with VEGF, improved biocompatibility, cell adhesion, and insulin secretion, demonstrating promising results for diabetes treatment. The scaffolds maintained cell respiration and formed cell clusters, indicating functional viability.
population_specificity: Insulin-producing cells in a laboratory setting (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of a silk/gelatin-based film and its ability to shield SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells from 6-OHDA-induced toxicity.
results_summary: The study found that silk fibroin (SF) had significant neuroprotective effects against 6-OHDA-induced toxicity in SH-SY5Y cells, and the silk/gelatin film effectively released SF, further confirming its protective capacity.
population_specificity: Human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an efficient method for sorting and expanding Muse cells from mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) using immune magnetic sorting and a dynamic microsphere carrier.
results_summary: The study found that Muse cells sorted from MSCs exhibited stronger pluripotency and differentiation ability compared to non-Muse cells, and their homing ability to muscle injury sites was superior. The dynamic microsphere carrier method improved the cultivation and expansion of Muse cells.
population_specificity: Human umbilical cord-derived mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) and Muse cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop gelatin-coated transferosomes (GLTS) for targeted delivery of tofacitinib to hair follicles to enhance treatment of alopecia areata.
results_summary: GLTS demonstrated high hair follicle localization and achieved up to 80% hair regrowth in AA patients after 12 weeks of treatment. The formulation showed enhanced clinical efficacy with positive patient feedback.
population_specificity: Seven AA patients (5 males, 2 females) with recalcitrant lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an injectable composite microgel (GPH) containing gelatin methacryloyl could synergistically inhibit bacteria, modulate immunity, remove ROS, and promote periodontal tissue repair and alveolar bone regeneration.
results_summary: The composite microgel demonstrated >99% antibacterial efficacy against E. coli, S. aureus, and P. gingivalis, scavenged 87.1% of DPPH, promoted macrophage shift from M1 to M2, reduced ROS, and significantly improved alveolar bone regeneration (25.94% bone volume vs. 22.3% in controls) while suppressing inflammation.
population_specificity: Study focused on an infected alveolar bone defect model (in vivo) and BMSC cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a multifunctional composite hydrogel using gelatin methacrylate (GelMA) combined with surface-imprinted chitosan-modified bioglass particles for controlled doxycycline release to manage periodontitis.
results_summary: The composite hydrogels demonstrated bioactive properties, including bone-like apatite formation, localized hemostasis, antioxidant and antibacterial effects, and improved cellular responses for osteogenic differentiation of human dental pulp stem cells.
population_specificity: Human dental pulp stem cells (hDPSCs) in vitro; no human subjects were mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of gelatin-derived core-shell nanoparticles (AC-PCL(GL + PTX)-GNPs) for managing precancerous lesions in colorectal cancer.
results_summary: The study found that the gelatin-based nanoparticles exhibited sustained drug release, synergistic anticancer effects in cell cultures, reduced precancerous lesions in vivo, and showed no significant toxicity or adverse effects.
population_specificity: HTC 116 and HT-29 colorectal cancer cell lines, and a 1,2-dimethyl hydrazine-induced colorectal cancer model in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a glucose-triggered, near-infrared-responsive photothermal antibacterial hydrogel (GOGD) based on gelatin and oxidized dextran for treating infected diabetic wounds.
results_summary: The GOGD hydrogel demonstrated glucose-triggered photothermal antibacterial properties, good biocompatibility, strong ROS scavenging ability, excellent hemostatic properties, and significantly enhanced healing of Staphylococcus aureus-infected diabetic wounds in a mouse model by regulating inflammation and promoting angiogenesis.
population_specificity: Mouse model with Staphylococcus aureus-infected diabetic wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the drug release, cytocompatibility, and therapeutic efficacy of GelMA hydrogel loaded with resolvin D1 (RvD1) in treating periodontal inflammation and alveolar bone damage.
results_summary: RvD1 complexed with GelMA effectively released RvD1, enhanced PDLC proliferation, reduced inflammation, and promoted bone regeneration in periodontitis. Micro-CT confirmed significant new bone formation in the treated group.
population_specificity: Rats with induced periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Weekly topical applications (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a mechanically viable, degradable biopolymer-based composite mesh using gelatin-MWCNT for hernia repair, focusing on improving mechanical strength and biocompatibility.
results_summary: The gelatin-MWCNT composite mesh showed improved ductility, printability, hydrophilicity, modulus, and reduced degradation rate. It also demonstrated cell attachment and proliferation, indicating non-toxicity and enhanced biocompatibility. The optimal composition was gelatin with 0.01 g MWCNTs, providing the best mechanical strength and biocompatibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if gelatin-based silver nanoparticles could enhance the antifungal efficacy of Terbinafine against Candida albicans strains.
results_summary: Gelatin-based silver nanoparticles improved the antifungal effectiveness of Terbinafine, particularly against C. albicans strain ATCC 90028, showing a synergistic effect and significant reduction in viable cell count.
population_specificity: Three strains of Candida albicans (ATCC 10231, ATCC 90028, and ATCC 18804).
effective_dosage: Not specified for gelatin; silver nanoparticles were produced with 30 mg of silver nitrate (AgNO₃).
study_duration: Stability studies spanned 60 days; intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate graphene oxide/gelatin/alginate scaffolds for advanced wound therapy, focusing on mimicking the native extracellular matrix and stimulating all phases of wound healing.
results_summary: The scaffolds exhibited high porosity, mechanical strength, biocompatibility, and stable adhesion to skin tissue, with no toxicity detected in vitro or in vivo. They also demonstrated significant potential for simultaneous release of active agents (allantoin, quercetin, and caffeic acid).
population_specificity: Fibroblasts (MRC5 cells) and Caenorhabditis elegans (in vivo model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physicochemical, mechanical, and biological properties of a CMC/Gel hydrogel wound dressing containing cefdinir for wound healing.
results_summary: The hydrogel dressing showed no cytotoxicity, enhanced antibacterial effects, and accelerated wound healing, with 60% healing by day 9 and over 85% by day 15. The addition of cefdinir improved antibacterial activity without significantly altering the dressing's mechanical properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and likely animal model based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal efficacy of a gelatin-based nanoemulsion system (T-GNE) combining terbinafine and essential oils against Candida albicans biofilms.
results_summary: The study found that the gelatin-based nanoemulsion system (T-GNE) with essential oils (eugenol, methyl eugenol, or carvacrol) and terbinafine showed additive or synergistic antifungal effects, effectively penetrating and disrupting C. albicans biofilms with minimal mammalian cell toxicity.
population_specificity: Candida albicans biofilms (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a GEL/PLGA/ATP scaffold equipped with TPTD microspheres for bone defect repair in tissue engineering.
results_summary: The GEL/PLGA/ATP scaffold with TPTD microspheres significantly enhanced BMSC proliferation and osteogenic differentiation, up-regulated osteoblast markers (COL1, RUNX2, OCN, OPN), and promoted extensive new bone formation in mice.
population_specificity: Mouse bone mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs) and skull defect models in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop in situ gelling nanofibers composed of gelatin and oxidized carboxymethyl cellulose (OCMC) for wound healing applications, evaluating their structural integrity, degradation, antibacterial properties, and biocompatibility.
results_summary: The study found that the OCMC/PVA-Gelatin nanofibers demonstrated excellent biocompatibility (91-92% cell viability), 99.9% antibacterial efficacy against P. aeruginosa and MRSA, and full degradation within 21 days, making them suitable for wound healing.
population_specificity: In vitro (L929 fibroblast cells) and bacterial cultures (P. aeruginosa, MRSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and characterize Ge/PLA/AuNCs (gelatin-based nanocomposites) and evaluate their biomedical applications, including antioxidant, antibacterial, anti-diabetic, and anti-Alzheimer properties.
results_summary: The study found that Ge/PLA/AuNCs exhibited strong antioxidant, antibacterial, anti-diabetic, and anti-Alzheimer activities, along with excellent biocompatibility and non-toxicity in zebrafish embryos and improved cell viability in SH-SY5Y cell lines.
population_specificity: Zebrafish embryos and SH-SY5Y cell lines (in vitro and in vivo models).
effective_dosage: 100 μg/mL (concentration used for antioxidant, antibacterial, and enzyme inhibition assays).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a polysaccharide-based composite hydrogel, incorporating gelatin microspheres, for treating aging skin wounds.
results_summary: The composite hydrogel reduced oxidative stress, inhibited bacterial growth, decreased inflammation, promoted angiogenesis, and enhanced collagen deposition, facilitating wound healing in aging mouse skin. Gelatin microspheres were used to embed Puerarin, contributing to the hydrogel's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Aging mice with skin wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating IgY and CeO2 NPs into PLGA/Gel-based dressings (P/G@IYCe) could enhance infected skin repair by improving antibacterial effects, inflammation resolution, and ROS scavenging.
results_summary: The P/G@IYCe dressings demonstrated significant antibacterial effects against S. aureus and E. coli in vitro, promoted scarless wound healing, reduced inflammation, and scavenged ROS in S. aureus-infected full-thickness wounds in rats.
population_specificity: Rats with S. aureus-infected full-thickness excisional defects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 3D-printed hydrogel combining sodium alginate and gelatin loaded with Aloe barbadensis extract for enhanced wound healing and scar reduction.
results_summary: The hydrogel demonstrated excellent mechanical properties, antibacterial activity, biocompatibility, and biodegradability. In vivo studies showed improved wound closure, reduced inflammation, and decreased scar formation after 14 days.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro models based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether donkey-hide gelatin-derived carbon dots (G-CDs) could effectively address stalled erythropoiesis and oxidative stress in aplastic anemia (AA).
results_summary: G-CDs promoted erythropoiesis, alleviated oxidative stress, and restored hematopoietic function in AA mice, outperforming erythropoietin (EPO) without adverse effects.
population_specificity: Chemotherapy-induced aplastic anemia mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how tilapia skin gelatin properties affect high internal phase emulsions (HIPEs) and their suitability for 3D printing.
results_summary: Gelatin degraded with increased heating intensity, with optimal emulsification and gel properties observed at 5 hours of heat treatment. HIPEs constructed with gelatin extracted at 70 °C were suitable for 3D printing, exhibiting a compact network structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of using gelatin sponge, recombinant bFGF, and fibrin glue for tympanic membrane perforation closure and hearing improvement.
results_summary: The study found an 84.1% closure rate for tympanic membrane perforations, with significant hearing improvement in successful cases and no serious complications reported. Closure was primarily achieved after the first or second treatment, with no further benefit from additional treatments.
population_specificity: 42 patients (44 ears) with tympanic membrane perforations treated at Yokosuka Kyosai Hospital.
study_duration: Treatment was repeated up to four times, with evaluations at least one month post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of PEGDA/gelatin hybrid hydrogels as uptake and release systems for photosensitizers in photodynamic therapy.
results_summary: Gelatin ratio and ionic properties influenced photosensitizer uptake, with anionic photosensitizers achieving over 80% uptake. Cationic photosensitizers produced singlet oxygen more efficiently, and hydrogels demonstrated photosensitizer-dependent cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 3D-printed hydrogel scaffold containing gelatin (G) for wound healing, focusing on biocompatibility, mechanical properties, and antibacterial activity.
results_summary: The 3D-printed SA-G-SAL scaffold demonstrated hydrophilicity, mechanical strength, antibacterial activity, hemocompatibility, and biocompatibility. In vivo tests showed improved wound closure rates, reduced inflammation, and minimal scar formation compared to controls.
population_specificity: Rat models with full-thickness wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a multifunctional antibacterial hydrogel dressing using gelatin and sodium alginate as the matrix to enhance sonodynamic therapy for diabetic wound healing.
results_summary: The hydrogel dressing demonstrated excellent antimicrobial ability under low-intensity ultrasound, effectively inhibiting biofilm formation and promoting wound healing in diabetic rats by enhancing granulation tissue formation, angiogenesis, and collagen deposition.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats with infected wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hydrogel scaffold incorporating methylacryloyl gelatin (GelMA) for supporting 3D tumor growth and drug resistance testing in colorectal cancer research.
results_summary: The study found that the GelMA-based scaffold improved hydrophilic properties, mechanical strength, and biocompatibility, supporting long-term tumor sphere growth and demonstrating high cell survival rates (88.06%) after 5-FU treatment compared to traditional 2D models.
population_specificity: Human colorectal cancer cells (HCT8) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how molecular weight distribution (MWD) of bovine bone gelatin affects gel strength and its interaction with microbial transglutaminase (MTGase) cross-linking.
results_summary: High-MW fractions were key in gelatin gel network formation, while low-MW fractions had negligible gelation ability. MTGase cross-linking significantly increased gel strength in both high- and low-MW samples, but gelatin with fewer high- and low-MW fractions showed decreased gel strength.
population_specificity: Bovine bone gelatin samples (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether GelMA@MP196/exos could promote immune microenvironment stability, enhance efferocytosis, and reduce periodontitis symptoms.
results_summary: GelMA@MP196/exos promoted neutrophil apoptosis, macrophage M2 polarization, and efferocytosis while demonstrating antibacterial activity against key periodontal pathogens. It also reduced alveolar bone loss in rat models.
population_specificity: Rat models with periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of gelatin biopolymer on altering the wettability of dolomite and calcite rocks for enhanced oil recovery.
results_summary: Gelatin treatment significantly reduced contact angles in oil-wet dolomite and calcite rocks to 38.40° and 34.52°, respectively, indicating effective wettability alteration. The Fe3O4/gelatin nanocomposite further enhanced this effect, reducing angles to 26.00° and 24.10°.
population_specificity: Dolomite and calcite rock specimens exposed to crude oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-serine-incorporated gelatin sponges could enhance bone regeneration and inhibit osteoclast activity in an osteoporotic rat model.
results_summary: The L-serine group showed significant increases in bone volume and bone area compared to controls, along with suppressed cathepsin K expression (a marker of osteoclast activity) and increased serine racemase activity. The findings suggest L-serine gelatin sponges promote bone formation while reducing bone resorption.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized rats (osteoporosis model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a dual-function gelatin/tannic acid-based hydrogel patch for skin protection and treatment of conditions like "maskne" and rosacea during prolonged mask use.
results_summary: The gelatin/tannic acid hydrogel patches demonstrated improved adhesivity, burst strength, and extensibility, with controlled drug release profiles for metronidazole and salicylic acid, suggesting effective skin protection and treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of sodium citrate and sodium bicarbonate on blood alkalosis and gastrointestinal symptoms when administered in gelatin capsules.
results_summary: The study found that both supplements induced similar blood alkalosis and gastrointestinal symptoms, but with different time courses (SC peaked later than SB). GIS were mostly minor, with no significant differences in severity or frequency between the two supplements.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy individuals
effective_dosage: Gelatin capsules ingested over 15 minutes alongside a carbohydrate-rich meal (specific gelatin dosage not provided)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) on anaerobic metabolism during exercise.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that NaHCO₃ ingestion affects the glycolytic system but not the oxidative system during exercise. The study did not address gelatin specifically.
population_specificity: Not specified (general exercise context implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic benefits of combining gelatin with bioactive glasses (BAG) for enhanced mechanical properties and controlled bioactivity in tissue engineering applications.
results_summary: The study found that gelatin-BAG composites improve mechanical properties and regulate ionic supplementation for better bioactivity and regenerative potential, with cellular benefits demonstrated in various functional modifications like zinc doping.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on in vitro or preclinical applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gelatin capsules (GEL) could mitigate gastrointestinal (GI) distress and alter acid-base balance compared to other forms of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) ingestion.
results_summary: Gelatin capsules (GEL) resulted in higher GI symptom severity compared to enteric-coated (ENT) capsules but showed no significant difference in blood bicarbonate concentration compared to placebo. ENT capsules were more effective in reducing GI symptoms and had a lower impact on blood bicarbonate levels than GEL.
population_specificity: Trained males (n = 14)

study_goal: The study does not address Gelatin; it focuses on a modified sodium bicarbonate ingestion protocol for elite middle-distance runners.
results_summary: The study found that the modified sodium bicarbonate protocol elevated serum bicarbonate concentration more effectively than acute ingestion, without severe gastrointestinal side effects.
population_specificity: Seven elite middle-distance runners (5 men, 2 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the regulatory framework for genetically modified organisms (GMOs) in Australia and its role in ensuring safety and efficacy.
results_summary: The study outlines Australia's Gene Technology Regulatory Scheme, which provides science-based risk assessments for GMOs, and highlights recent reforms to support safe development of gene-based therapeutics.
population_specificity: Not specified (regulatory framework analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the regulatory challenges and delays in clinical trials for gene therapies containing GMOs in the EU and advocate for legislative exemptions.
results_summary: The abstract reports that compliance with GMO legislation in the EU causes delays in clinical trials for gene therapies, making the region less attractive for such trials. It argues that ATMPs pose negligible environmental risk and calls for exemptions to accelerate patient access.
population_specificity: Not specified (focuses on regulatory and legislative context rather than a specific patient population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of the EU's regulatory framework for assessing environmental risks of gene therapy medicinal products containing genetically modified organisms, focusing on streamlining the process for clinical trials and marketing authorizations.
results_summary: The abstract discusses a new streamlined procedure for assessing environmental risks of gene therapy products with genetically modified organisms, aiming to facilitate consistent evaluation and faster patient access, but does not report specific study findings on safety or efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (focuses on regulatory processes, not a specific patient population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the successes and failures of genetically modified organisms used in vaccination against major parasitic diseases, particularly leishmaniasis.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the progression of vaccine development for leishmaniasis, from killed parasite vaccines to live recombinant and attenuated vaccines, noting promising results but emphasizing the need for further evaluation of potential genes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on leishmaniasis vaccination research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin E (delivered in a gelatin capsule) combined with vitamin C could protect breast-cancer patients from chemotherapy-induced oxidative damage.
results_summary: The study found that VCE supplementation (including vitamin E in gelatin capsules) significantly improved antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced lipid peroxidation, and decreased DNA damage compared to chemotherapy alone. The results suggest protective effects against chemotherapy-related oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Forty untreated stage II breast-cancer patients.
effective_dosage: Vitamin E 400 mg (gelatin capsule) and vitamin C 500 mg tablet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of the legal basis, requirements, and scientific principles for environmental risk assessment (ERA) of GMO-containing medicinal products in the EU and clinical trials in Germany.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the necessity of ERA for GMO-containing medicinal products to identify potential risks to public health and the environment, and proposes risk management strategies if risks are deemed unacceptable. It outlines legal and methodological frameworks but does not present specific study results on GMO safety or efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (focuses on regulatory and methodological context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) expressing egfp::zhd101 in detoxifying zearalenone (ZEN) and to assess the correlation between fluorescence intensity and enzymatic activity.
results_summary: The study found that recombinant E. coli and transgenic rice calluses effectively degraded ZEN and exhibited strong fluorescence, while recombinant Saccharomyces cerevisiae showed poor fluorescence and incomplete detoxification, converting residual ZEN into beta-zearalenol. Despite this, the yeast transformant detoxified 75% of ZEN, outperforming existing Lactobacillus-based systems.
population_specificity: In vitro and transgenic organisms (E. coli, rice calluses, Saccharomyces cerevisiae).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the applicability of quantifying genetically modified (GM) maize and soy in processed foods using heat treatment models and PCR analysis.
results_summary: The study found that the size of PCR products significantly influences GM quantification in processed foods, with the conversion factor (Cf) stabilizing when PCR product sizes were nearly equal. Additionally, the Cf of endosperm was influenced by whether the GM originated from paternal or maternal sources, complicating GM% determination in maize grains and processed foods.
population_specificity: Processed foods derived from GM maize (MON810) and glyphosate-tolerant Roundup Ready (RR) soy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of red ginger on the sensory attributes and physicochemical properties of moringa-based instant beverages.
results_summary: Red ginger emerged as the most preferred by panelists, scoring highest in color, aroma, and taste. It enhanced the sensory appeal of the beverage, increasing consumer acceptance likelihood.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study with panelists, likely general adult population).
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested as an herbal addition, but exact dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: Not specified (study duration not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of short-term weak static magnetic field (SWMF) stimulation on the metabolite profiles and metabolic pathways of fresh-cut young ginger (FCYG).
results_summary: The study found that fresh-cut treatment caused significant losses of volatile terpenes and changes in primary and secondary metabolites in FCYG, while 5 mT SWMF treatment better preserved these metabolites by inhibiting respiration and energy-related pathways.
population_specificity: Fresh-cut young ginger (FCYG)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of ginger's bioactive compounds on cardiovascular diseases, including its potential to improve cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that ginger has antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory properties, which may improve cardiovascular risk factors such as fasting blood glucose, triglyceride, and LDL levels. It suggests ginger could be a safer alternative with fewer side effects for preventing and treating CVDs.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of potential effects on cardiovascular diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a combination of medicinal plants, including Ginger, on the recovery and outcome of COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of medicinal plants, including Ginger, significantly improved oxygen saturation (SpO2) and reduced C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in COVID-19 patients compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: 150 COVID-19 patients receiving standard care treatment.
effective_dosage: Two capsules of herbal medicine orally every 8 hours (specific Ginger dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ginger supplementation on antioxidant status, biochemical parameters, and intestinal tissue histopathology in broiler chicks with experimentally induced coccidiosis.
results_summary: Ginger extract reduced fecal oocyst counts, ameliorated leukocyte alterations, reversed biochemical parameter changes, increased CD4 T cell counts, and restored normal cecal histological structure in infected chicks.
population_specificity: One hundred one-day-old broiler chicks (Ross breed).
effective_dosage: 6 gm/L of water, administered orally via drinking water.
study_duration: 25 days (varied by group, with some receiving ginger for the full duration and others starting post-infection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ginger supplementation in managing hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) symptoms in pregnant women.
results_summary: Ginger supplementation significantly reduced nausea and vomiting symptoms (pooled odds ratio 0.41, 95% CI: 0.22-0.79, P = 0.008) and was well-tolerated with minimal side effects and no significant harm to maternal or fetal health.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with hyperemesis gravidarum (HG).
effective_dosage: Various forms (capsules, powders, biscuits) – specific dosage not detailed in abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Ginger (Zingiber officinale) and Schisandra chinensis drug pairs (DSP) on intestinal flora and bile acid metabolism in rats with asthma caused by cold, to provide experimental evidence for its clinical application.
results_summary: DSP reduced asthma inflammation by regulating FOXP3 and TGF-β1 in Treg cells, altered gut microbiota (reducing harmful bacteria and increasing beneficial bacteria), and modified bile acid metabolism (increasing DCA and decreasing ACA, GLCA, GCDCA, and GUDCA).
population_specificity: Male rats with induced asthma via OVA + ice water swimming.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether salicylic acid nanoliposomes (SA@NLs) could alleviate chilling injury in baby ginger by modulating membrane lipid metabolism.
results_summary: SA@NLs treatment effectively maintained the quality of baby ginger, reduced phospholipid degradation, and increased unsaturated fatty acid content, enhancing membrane fluidity and chilling tolerance.
population_specificity: Baby ginger (a specific variety of ginger)
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated (implied by "end of storage")

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of ginger extract in osteosarcoma (OS) by identifying its antineoplastic mechanisms and validating c-MET as a target.
results_summary: Ginger extract inhibited OS cell proliferation, induced apoptosis, and suppressed tumor growth in vitro and in vivo. c-MET was identified as a target, and its knockdown confirmed its role in OS progression.
population_specificity: Osteosarcoma (OS) cells and patient-derived xenograft (PDX) models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different light quality ratios and photoperiods on ginger's phenotypic traits, dry matter production, and yield.
results_summary: Blue light treatment reduced plant height but increased stem diameter, tiller number, leaf area, and yield, while prolonged photoperiods enhanced plant height, stem diameter, and biomass, redistributing photosynthetic products to rhizomes and boosting yield.
population_specificity: Ginger plants under controlled light conditions.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (light quality and photoperiod conditions were manipulated, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aromatherapy with ginger, combined with peppermint and lavender, reduces the severity of postoperative nausea in oral surgery patients under general anesthesia.
results_summary: Aromatherapy significantly reduced nausea severity (p < 0.001) and improved patient satisfaction (p < 0.001), though antiemetic use did not differ significantly between groups. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing postoperative nausea after oral surgery under general anesthesia in a Japanese hospital setting.
effective_dosage: 0.01 ml of pure ginger essential oil (diluted to 1%).
study_duration: Single intervention at the onset of postoperative nausea.

study_goal: To examine the effects of phenolic compound-rich ginger extract on motor and cognitive functions and cytokine levels in a mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) model.
results_summary: Ginger extract significantly improved motor and cognitive functions and reduced elevated cytokine levels in rats with mTBI, whether administered before or after injury.
population_specificity: Rats with induced mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the optimal synergistic ratio between Citrus aurantium L. var. amara (CAVA) and ginger for anti-obesity effects and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that two specific CAVA-ginger combinations (C3 and A1) significantly prevented weight gain in mice, improved lipid profiles, and modulated gut microbiota, with the best anti-obesity effect at a 37:63 ratio. The C3 group showed reduced TC and LDL-C, while the A1 group reduced TG, and both increased beneficial gut bacteria like Akkermansia.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese C57BL/6J mice
effective_dosage: Not specified (nine different ratios of aqueous extracts tested)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of replacing peanut straw with ginger straw on goat growth, meat quality, rumen fermentation, and immunity.
results_summary: Replacing peanut straw with ginger straw improved goat growth performance, rumen fermentation, immunity, and intestinal barrier function, with the 5% replacement showing the highest digestibility and growth benefits. No adverse effects on meat quality were observed.
population_specificity: 40 Huanghuai male goats, six months old, weighing 30 ± 0.5 kg.
effective_dosage: 0%, 5%, 10%, and 20% ginger straw replacing peanut straw in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the causative agents of bacterial wilt in ginger plants in China and confirm their pathogenicity.
results_summary: The study identified Enterobacter kobei and Enterobacter mori as new causal agents of ginger bacterial wilt in China, confirmed their pathogenicity through inoculation tests, and provided genetic sequencing data for future management strategies.
population_specificity: Ginger plants (Tongling White Ginger) in Yi'an District, Tongling City, Anhui Province, China.
study_duration: Symptoms appeared within five days post-inoculation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginger-derived extracellular vesicles (Gin-EVs) could alleviate liver fibrosis progression and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Gin-EVs effectively protected human hepatic stellate cells (LX-2) from CCL4 or LPS-induced liver fibrosis by mitigating fibrosis, enhancing cell viability, and counteracting mitochondrial dysfunction through restored mitochondrial dynamics and biogenesis.
population_specificity: Human hepatic stellate cells (LX-2) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective and antioxidant effects of methanolic extract from Cheilocostus speciosus (crepe-ginger) flowers.
results_summary: The study found that the methanolic extract exhibited significant antioxidant activity in vitro (DPPH and ABTS assays) and improved liver function markers (AST, ALT, ALP, etc.) in vivo, along with preserving hepatocyte integrity in histopathological analysis. Phytochemical screening and GC-MS/MS identified 40 compounds, suggesting potential for further research.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo experiments likely used animal models, but abstract does not clarify).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-cell viability and anti-tumorigenicity effects of zingerone nanoparticles derived from ginger on human colorectal cancer cell lines.
results_summary: Zingerone nanoparticles significantly inhibited cell viability and tumorigenicity in CRC cell lines, disrupted cell cycle progression, and induced apoptosis by modulating key signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Human colorectal cancer cell lines (LoVo and HCT116).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which ginger extract induces the regeneration of functional β-cells in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Ginger extract significantly up-regulated Neurog3 and Mafb expression after one week, followed by increased Ins2 and Gcg expression after eight weeks, leading to restored β-cell mass, improved serum insulin levels, weight gain, and lowered fasting blood glucose in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic Sprague-Dawley rats (n=27).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Bacillus paralicheniformis SYN-191 could improve ginger growth, yield, and soil health by antagonizing pathogenic fungi and restructuring microbial communities.
results_summary: The study found that SYN-191 inhibited Fusarium ramigenum, improved ginger agronomic traits, increased yield by 26.47%, and enhanced beneficial microbial populations in rhizosphere soil.
population_specificity: Ginger plants and their rhizosphere soil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a ginger-derived nanoplatform (GDNPs@ICG) to enhance the efficacy of photo-mediated therapy for breast tumors.
results_summary: GDNPs@ICG improved photothermal performance, generated high ROS levels, and significantly inhibited breast tumor growth in vivo with limited toxicity. It also reduced angiogenesis, inhibited metastasis, activated anti-tumor immune responses, and promoted cell senescence.
population_specificity: Breast tumor models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether furanodienone (FDN), a major component of ginger, acts as a selective pregnane X receptor (PXR) ligand and has anti-inflammatory effects in the colon.
results_summary: The study found that FDN binds to the PXR ligand binding domain, altering its structure, and demonstrates potent PXR-dependent anti-inflammatory effects specific to the colon in male mice. The presence of synergistically acting agonists suggests potential for enhancing FDN's activity, efficacy, and safety.
population_specificity: Male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of dietary ginger and its derivatives on fish health, growth, and disease resistance in aquaculture.
results_summary: The study found that ginger and its derivatives improved growth performance, flesh quality, immune responses, antioxidative activity, and disease resistance in fish, with optimal dietary doses ranging from 0.0002% to 4%.
population_specificity: Fish in aquaculture settings.
